content.body: MikeSmith: I figured out that jsdom issue
oh?
cool
what was the problem?
If you require('jsdom/level1/core') instead of require('jsdom/level2/core'), it works
tries it
var DOM = browser.browserAugmentation(require('jsdom/level1/core').dom.level1.core)
(is the replacement for the relevant line)
seet
sweet
I guess the level2 stuff is pre-alpha
yeah
html->atom is much nicer with things like createElementNS
but I guess I can fake it for now
yeah
so after that change is htmlparser working now for you? (for what you were using it for)
and should I post a follow-up comment to the bug you pointed me to before?
Oh. I haven't been using node-htmlparser at all; I've been using aredridel/html5
which is essentially html5lib in js
hober: yeah, that's the one I meant
aredridel/html5 has been working for me. at least, last I remember screwing with this stuff it seemed to work.
but creating new documents from whole cloth was failing, and now I know it's due to my premature desire to use level 2 DOM methods.
among other things, I'm wondering how its performance is relative to html5lib (python) or to whatever non-HTML5 parsers you might have tried (e.g., the HTML parser in libxml2)
for my current purposes (offline, static site generation), I'm not terribly concerned about performance
ok
(that said, I imagine I'm the outlier, Node.js-wise, insofar as performance concerns go.)
I'm working on a publication workflow in which the "pretty this HTML up for publication" logic can happen browser-side, during composition, and server-side, when the publish button is pressed
(the prettyifying code being exactly the same)
yeah, that's a really nice advantage to have
(being able to use the same code server side and client both)
The longer-term idea I'm working on, in a somewhat cryptic tweet: http://twitter.com/hober/status/15739328281
hober: interesting
jgraham: Listening to Rasputina again, I again conclude they're not my sort of music.
Hixie, <details> changes the DOM based on user interaction
I wish I had paid closer attention to DOM Events
annevk: you mean because you think it has problems that should have been fixed before now?
I think it might have and I think it would have helped to point them out at early stages
I see
I guess that's true in general of any spec
Yep
See e.g. all the RDF nonsense to describe something as simple as WAI-ARIA
but some are more important than others and it doesn't harm as much to have ignored them
makes it completely unreadable, but it's not going to change for this edition
oh
I can see that's a problem
but not quite as serious as I thought you might have meant
well, real serious ends up getting ignored at the implementation stage
yeah
e.g. various things that were once in SVG 1.2
yeah, i know
as far as browsers go at least
which is what's really important of course
semi-serious things -- like how the CSS syntax is insanely complicated if you look at the details while it did not have to be at all -- need to be tackled sooner rather than later
um, what's exactly the RDF part you're referring to?
there's no reason that the character sequence "@namespace" can be written in near-infinite ways
http://www.w3.org/TR/wai-aria/roles is full of it
"superclassing" "subclassing" etc.
all kinds of complexity that a) authors are not interested in and b) implementations are not either
on the face of it, that seems like the same kind of overengineering that's a misfeature of a lot of specs
but maybe it could be useful in some complex apps
I mean, I don't myself know all what's involved in adding ARIA to a complex app like Gmail or whatever
hmm, I think browsing with Disable Caches set in Webkit/Safari seems to possibly be a great way to cause the fan on your laptop to run at high speeds continuously
I think it might be causing "Safari Webpage Preview Fetcher" to keep launching and re-launching to fetch previews of pages that then don't get cached anywhere, and so it fetches them again and again
maybe
"defaults write com.apple.Safari DebugSnapshotsUpdatePolicy -int 2" seems to possibly be the way to stop it
sitepoint.com pop-ups are really cheesy
I thought the people behind Sitepoint were better than that
the inconsistency of the format support table at http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HTML5_video annoys me again. It's even more bogus thatn before.
I vented on the talk page, since the page itself is guarded by a user with an intimidatingly long user page
people with *huge* user pages always have the time to out-revert you, so why even bother
So there's no window in workers, only self?
yup

hsivonen: dunno how much time if any you've had lately to think about migrating the v.nu sources to a git or mercurial hosting service, but I wanted to say I'd be willing to do the work to make it happen
that is, dealing with actually getting them migrated over, as well as updating the build script and whatever else would be needed
github seems like it might best place to consider moving to
for among other reasons the network effects of the fact that there are so many very active developers there
github supports svn, btw
(see http://github.com/blog/644-subversion-write-support for more)
hober: part of the motivation is to get away from svn, actually
at least on my part
I've never been a big subversion fan
I really that github makes it dead simple to fork repos
github's svn support is actually git-backed. it lets people who aren't yet comfortable with git use something familiar while the other collaborators forge on ahead with git
ah, I see
well that's good then
e.g. svn checkout http://svn.github.com/sideshowbarker/jsblog.git
(use https for a read/write checkout)
cool
there more I use github, the more I like it
it ain't perfect but it was clearly designed by people with clue
and in general it just seems to work the way a system like that ought to
yeah, those guys are rad
the ease of forking and the culture really encourage experimentation
I think getting the validator.nu sources available there might help a lot toward getting some code contributions for yet-to-be-implemented features and bugs too
it'd raise more awareness about it and hopeflly get some more good devs involved
heh
http://www.xtranormal.com/watch/6995033/ is pretty good
the first couple of minutes at least
MikeSmith: still working on your KO?
well, I'm just working on a personal KO
I don't want to embarrass myself by bringing much attention to it yet
but so far I've messed around a bit with express, Connect, and the ext.js stuff
and it's all really quite nice
and of course the fork I made of brianleroux's wtfs stuff
gotta love that dude
his comments in the "templating" part of that About page for that site are great

Nothing is perfect. And sometimes shit is just plain wack. The ExpressJS framework is seriously awesome but it has a hardon for HAML which solves problems I do not have. I opted, out of lazyness, for EJS which is not beautiful; tho it is functional.
that part
http://wtfjs.com/about
micheil: what'd you got cooked up for KO?
well, I'm judging, but I am working on a canvas game thuing
MikeSmith: y'know, I could always track down the repo :P
I'm just at the rubbing-two-sticks-together-to-make-fire stage
but then again, that's pretty much the stage at which all the code I write remains
regardless of what language it's written in
a one-man coding WTF
MikeSmith: deployed anything yet?
nope
MikeSmith: what was your team name?
no team, man
do you wish to have a team?
that would make you officially part of KO
yeah, in general
I prefer always to have other people to do my work for me when I can
okay, shoot an email to all⊙nc asking if you could have a team created for yourself
hai
oh!
somebody from japan showing up on the map finally
connection
walter-sobchak
I thought he didn't code on shabbas
heh
they have done some impressive work so far -
http://walter-sobchak.no.de/
bold, minimalist approach
hmm.. does unsaing-daiva keep coming up on the map?
*unsaving
ah, my Webkit nightly seems to have a turned itself into a torture-testing tool for the fan on the laptop
to see how long it can continuously run at full speed until it quits completely
hmm, or maybe it's just that tab I had up for the xtranormal movie I started making 3 hours ago and forgot about til now...
How did noscript get all the way to issue status?

It was "raised for Shelley Powers" whose "purpose in wanting to file change proposals isn't that I expected any of them to succeed", so presumably the point is just to waste time and/or to make a point
So there's no filtering at all on issues now, any bug that gets closed has a free promotion card?
hey, it's the voice of micheil
http://thechangelog.com/post/927103350/episode-0-3-1-websockets
it is
didn't I post that?
I mean, didn't I post a link to that in here?
micheil: probably I missed it
okay
well, enjoy :)
micheil: you didn't say so much on that podcast
those other dudes talk too much
not really
it was actually pretty interesting though
I'm meant to be a host, so, it's focusing on the guests
it gets' kinda awkward though when you interview guests and can answer the other's questions
hmm.. http://unsaving-daiva.no.de/
